Issues.Title: async event `this.` can't get the new data ,but this  can get the latest data（异步事件执行完后 无法通过this. 的方式获取data的最新数据）
Issues.Body:
### Version
2.6.11

### Reproduction link
[https://codepen.io/jadepam-the-bashful/pen/XWXqXoQ](https://codepen.io/jadepam-the-bashful/pen/XWXqXoQ)







### Steps to reproduce
页面初次加载执行fn1方法，fn异步方法未执行完，重新进入页面执行fn2，fn2执行完后，更新this数据（this.$set 更新数据任然无效，直接将数据挂载在window上f1可获取最新数据）；fn1执行完，在fn1方法中无法通过`this.`获取最新的数据，但是打印出this对象时，可以看到数据已经是最新。
1、mounted do fn1，the  fn1 unfinished ，
2、mounted do fn2，the fn2 finished，update this.url
3、fn1 finished , can't get the new data by this.url，consloe.log(this)  can get the latest data

### What is expected?
f1 can get the latest data

### What is actually happening?
f1 can’t get the latest data

<!-- generated by vue-issues. DO NOT REMOVE -->
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "async event `this.` can't get the new data ,but this  can get the latest data（异步事件执行完后 无法通过this. 的方式获取data的最新数据）" (#11506)

Issues.Title: A not operator (!) in a template breaks hot reloading
Issues.Body: ### Version 2.6.11 ### Reproduction link [https://jsfiddle.net/drnyt/sxj18w49/7/](https://jsfiddle.net/drnyt/sxj18w49/7/) ### Steps to reproduce - NPM version 6.14.5 - vue create vue-todo ``` ``` - Adding the not operator (!) to the following line: `{{btnState ? "The button is disabled" : "The button is active"}}` to `{{!btnState ? "The button is disabled" : "The button is active"}}` works and prints button is active, but removing the not operator (!) at this point would stop hot reloading. - You can open the same link `http://localhost:8080/` in another tab without restarting and it will work again until you repeat the steps above. ### What is expected? Hot reload stays active after removing a not operator (!) from the template. ### What is actually happening? Hot reload stops working after removing the not operator (!) from the template. --- - Works fine on JSFiddle Tested on: - Google Chrome | Version 83.0.4103.116 (Official Build) (64-bit) - Microsoft Edge (Chromium) | Version 83.0.478.58 (Official Build) (64-bit)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "A not operator (!) in a template breaks hot reloading" (#11504)

Issues.Title: Setting image src to '...' produces an unrelated error message
Issues.Body: ### Version 2.6.11 ### Reproduction link [https://github.com/cioccarellia/vue-isrc-mr](https://github.com/cioccarellia/vue-isrc-mr) ### Steps to reproduce - Clone the given repository, and then serve the project. - Alternatively, on any vuejs project, set the `` `src` property to be `...` ### What is expected? A clean error message, saying that the developer set the image `src` property to `...` (Maybe copying some placeholder code), which does not point to anything, and reporting the developer attention to the right file and right line number. ### What is actually happening? A completely unrelated error message is printed out, regarding the `cache-loader` module, which was not even installed in my package. I may suggest (though, my Vue knowledge is limited about how it works this deep down, so take it with a grain of salt) that Vue is actually trying to parse the `...` string as a module name or cache id, and it isn't finding any match. --- I copied some code from https://getbootstrap.org because I needed to recreate a specific design for a project, but then caught up in something else, and assumed that the code I copied would have worked. (With placeholder text and without any image, but it would have worked.) Instead of checking the web app, I went on working and coding other things and later I got the error you can check on the repository. ``` ERROR Failed to compile with 1 errors 11:42:48 PM This dependency was not found: * ... in ./node_modules/cache-loader/dist/cjs.js?{"cacheDirectory":"node_modules/.cache/vue-loader","cacheIdentifier":"2deff992-vue-loader-template"}!./node_modules/vue-loader/lib/loaders/templateLoader.js??vue-loader-options!./node_modules/cache-loader/dist/cjs.js??ref--0-0!./node_modules/vue-loader/lib??vue-loader-options!./src/App.vue?vue&type=template&id=7ba5bd90& To install it, you can run: npm install --save ... ``` I tried nearly everything, from running `npm clean-install`, to removing my OS cache folder and rebooting, and then removing / downgrading modules, until I finally went back to older commits in my git history. Thankfully I could narrow it down and get why it wasn't working, but anyway I've thrown away a couple of hours and raised my stress level over the standard Monday average :) I'd have never though that Vue would misbehave so much for such an html error, and it will be nice if it'd be fixed.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Setting image src to '...' produces an unrelated error message" (#11500)

Issues.Title: Potential XSS DOM attack code in updateDOMProps method
Issues.Body:
### What problem does this feature solve?
```updateDOMProps()``` method contains the line  ```svgContainer.innerHTML = "<svg>"   cur   "</svg>";```  which can be a potential source for XSS DOM attacks, as the element's value is not being properly sanitized or validated

### What does the proposed API look like?
Use
```
svgContainer.textContent  = "<svg>"   cur   "</svg>";
```
Instend of
```
svgContainer.innerHTML = "<svg>"   cur   "</svg>";
```

<!-- generated by vue-issues. DO NOT REMOVE -->
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Potential XSS DOM attack code in updateDOMProps method" (#11498)

To be

Issues.Title: Dynamic-and-async component works unless produced from a function call
Issues.Body:
### Version 2.6.11 ### Reproduction link [https://jsfiddle.net/9uj5nc8m/69/](https://jsfiddle.net/9uj5nc8m/69/) ### Steps to reproduce - Define one component with `` where `asyncComponent` is an async component constructor such as `() => Promise.resolve({ template: "

I've rendered!

" })` - Define another component with `` where `makeAsyncComponent` *returns* an async component constructor ### What is expected? Both components properly render ### What is actually happening? Only the first component properly renders. The second component falls into an infinite update loop without ever properly rendering. --- The docs are unclear as to whether or not dynamic-and-async components are allowed. [The docs say say](https://vuejs.org/v2/guide/components.html#Dynamic-Components) that for a dynamic component, the `:is` prop should evaluate to "either: [the] name of a registered component, [or] a component's option object". This doesn't allow the possibility of `:is` returning an [async component constructor](https://vuejs.org/v2/guide/components-dynamic-async.html#Async-Components), which is a function returning a promise. Despite this, my example shows that a dynamic-and-async component *does* work sometimes (but only sometimes). Because the docs are unclear, I can't actually claim that this is certainly a bug. If dynamic-and-async components are intended to work, it is. If they are not, then Vue should disallow the case that happens to work and/or print a warning in the console.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Dynamic-and-async component works unless produced from a function call" (#11492)

Issues.Title: Evaluating v-for in recursive component behaves differently in production and development mode
Issues.Body:
### Version
2.6.11

### Reproduction link
[https://github.com/MoritzW3L/VueRecursiveIssue](https://github.com/MoritzW3L/VueRecursiveIssue)







### Steps to reproduce
1.) Clone the Repo
2.) Run `npm i`
3.) 
  a) run `npm run serve` and observe the output
  b) run `npm run serve_prod` and observe the outputs
4.) Compare the two outputs


### What is expected?
The Rendering should not change behaviour between the two modes.  
In case of the minimal Example, either all recursive elements should always be rendered (optimal) or they should not be rendered regardless of mode. (Would require my code/approach to change but consistency is the issue for me here.)

### What is actually happening?
In development-mode all recursive elements are rendered.
If started in production-mode. any recursive rendering is disabled.

---
- I used typescript and vue-property-decorator in my example but filed it under Vue. I hope this is acceptable as I dont think there should be too much impact those decisions should have.
- Repository was created using vue-cli selecting only Typescript and using class syntax.
- If there is a workaround, the edge-case section of the docs does not describe it.
- In my minimal reproduction I provided the scripts: 'serve' and 'serve_prod' for easy testing of the issue.

<!-- generated by vue-issues. DO NOT REMOVE -->
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Evaluating v-for in recursive component behaves differently in production and development mode" (#11486)

Issues.Title: Template string render vulnerability
Issues.Body:
### Version
2.6.11

### Reproduction link
[https://codesandbox.io/s/cranky-moser-p90di?file=/src/main.js](https://codesandbox.io/s/cranky-moser-p90di?file=/src/main.js)







### Steps to reproduce
Put valid <script> element in template string

### What is expected?
Script should be blocked from executing

### What is actually happening?
Script executes

---
As the example illustrates, if a <script> element is the sole element passed into the template string of a component, it will execute said script block. However if it's pre-ceded by a valid element, eg: a div the script is blocked from execution by the renderer. You do not have to close said element as shown in examples, simply preceding the script tag with a valid opening tag suffices. I believe this is because the renderer automatically closes elements with missing closures.

<!-- generated by vue-issues. DO NOT REMOVE -->
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Template string render vulnerability" (#11483)

Issues.Title: Allow devs to specify port when running `npm test`
Issues.Body:
### What problem does this feature solve?
When I was testing a fix for #11480, I wasn't able to complete `npm test` apparently because I already had a GitLab instance running which is listening on port 8080, and I didn't want to take it down.  (If there is already a way to specify an alternate port I didn't see it, and it should be documented).

The test failed as follows.  Successfully passed tests are removed for brevity.

```
vue (spelling-fixes-warmsocks *=) $ npm test
> vue@2.6.11 test /home/scase/vue
> npm run lint && flow check && npm run test:types && npm run test:cover && npm run test:e2e -- --env phantomjs && npm run test:ssr && npm run test:weex

 # passed tests ...

> vue@2.6.11 test:e2e /home/scase/vue
> npm run build -- web-full-prod,web-server-basic-renderer && node test/e2e/runner.js "--env" "phantomjs"


> vue@2.6.11 build /home/scase/vue
> node scripts/build.js "web-full-prod,web-server-basic-renderer"

dist/vue.min.js 91.44kb (gzipped: 33.30kb)
events.js:291
      throw er; // Unhandled 'error' event
      ^

Error: listen EADDRINUSE: address already in use :::8080
    at Server.setupListenHandle [as _listen2] (net.js:1316:16)
    at listenInCluster (net.js:1364:12)
    at Server.listen (net.js:1450:7)
    at HttpServer.listen (/home/scase/vue/node_modules/http-server/lib/http-server.js:138:22)
    at Object.<anonymous> (/home/scase/vue/test/e2e/runner.js:8:8)
    at Module._compile (internal/modules/cjs/loader.js:1201:30)
    at Object.Module._extensions..js (internal/modules/cjs/loader.js:1221:10)
    at Module.load (internal/modules/cjs/loader.js:1050:32)
    at Function.Module._load (internal/modules/cjs/loader.js:938:14)
    at Function.executeUserEntryPoint [as runMain] (internal/modules/run_main.js:71:12)
Emitted 'error' event on Server instance at:
    at emitErrorNT (net.js:1343:8)
    at processTicksAndRejections (internal/process/task_queues.js:80:21) {
  code: 'EADDRINUSE',
  errno: -98,
  syscall: 'listen',
  address: '::',
  port: 8080
}
npm ERR! code ELIFECYCLE
npm ERR! errno 1
npm ERR! vue@2.6.11 test:e2e: `npm run build -- web-full-prod,web-server-basic-renderer && node test/e2e/runner.js "--env" "phantomjs"`
npm ERR! Exit status 1
npm ERR! 
npm ERR! Failed at the vue@2.6.11 test:e2e script.
npm ERR! This is probably not a problem with npm. There is likely additional logging output above.

npm ERR! A complete log of this run can be found in:
npm ERR!     /home/scase/.npm/_logs/2020-07-01T00_33_12_846Z-debug.log
npm ERR! Test failed.  See above for more details.
```



### What does the proposed API look like?
First, document the feature:

```bash
    $ npm test --help

    npm test [--port <number>] [-- <args>] 

    aliases: tst, t
```

Second, provide a suggestion when the issue is hit, as in this pseudo code change to test/e2e/runner.js:
```javascript
    try {
        server.listen(server_port)
    }
    catch (err) {
         if (err is EADDRINUSE) {
            throw "Port "   server_port   " is already in use.  You can change it by doing npm test --port <portnumber>"
        }
        else  { 
            throw err;
        }
    }
```
Third, implement the feature.  The command line:
```bash
    $ npm test --port 8111
```

I tried the above, and at first glance it looked to me like it was going to work:
 ```bash
3sc3396:/home/scase/vue (dev *=) $ npm test --port 8111

> vue@2.6.11 test /home/scase/vue
> npm run lint && flow check && npm run test:types && npm run test:cover && npm run test:e2e -- --env phantomjs && npm run test:ssr && npm run test:weex "8111"
```
... but it eventually failed the same way as in the problem description. 

I found these hard-coded port numbers in `test/` which may have to change:
```
3sc3396:/home/scase/vue (dev *=) $ grep -r -i 8080 test
test/e2e/runner.js:server.listen(8080)
test/e2e/specs/commits.js:    .url('http://localhost:8080/examples/commits/')
test/e2e/specs/todomvc.js:    .url('http://localhost:8080/examples/todomvc/#test')

test/e2e/specs/todomvc.js:    browser.url('http://localhost:8080/examples/todomvc/#completed')
test/e2e/specs/async-edge-cases.js:    .url('http://localhost:8080/test/e2e/specs/async-edge-cases.html')
```

This would allow casual contributors to run a complete test cycle more easily without disrupting anything they may have set up already.

Issues.Title: Spelling errors found with CodeSpell 1.17.1
Issues.Body:
Edit: markdown formatting
### Version
2.6.11

### Reproduction link
[https://github.com/warmsocks/vue/commit/8b18bdca7c61da779d65b681de557e9e24c29a93](https://github.com/warmsocks/vue/commit/8b18bdca7c61da779d65b681de557e9e24c29a93)







### Steps to reproduce
1. Install codespell.  1.17.1 is current as of this writing.  Instructions and info here:  https://github.com/codespell-project/codespell
1. Clone vue repo, ensure you are on dev branch
1. Run codespell, ignoring generated objects, the .git dir and quiet warnings about binary files:
```vue (dev *=) $ codespell -q2 --skip  packages,node_modules,dist,.git,coverage```


### What is expected?
Codespell should not find any real spelling errors.

### What is actually happening?
Codespell finds a handful of misspellings.  Ignoring false hits from things like variable names, it finds these:
```
./src/compiler/parser/index.js:383: anyting ==> anything
./types/umd.d.ts:10: backword ==> backward
./test/unit/features/directives/on.spec.js:283: modifers ==> modifiers
./test/unit/features/directives/on.spec.js:408: build-in ==> built-in
./test/unit/features/directives/on.spec.js:423: build-in ==> built-in
./flow/weex.js:31: informations ==> information
```

---
I have a fix.  I will submit a PR.

You might consider adding codespell checking, with proper exclusions, to npm test to reduce the chance of additional spelling errors in the future.

Issues.Title: Passing slots through in wrapper component
Issues.Body:
### Version
2.6.11

### Reproduction link
[https://codesandbox.io/s/romantic-mahavira-1s4v6](https://codesandbox.io/s/romantic-mahavira-1s4v6)







### Steps to reproduce
See the content below "Wrapper"

### What is expected?
All three variants, deprecated and new syntax in either order, should produce the same result

### What is actually happening?
All produce different results. In the example the final 'new syntax' variant seems fine, but it doesn't work with Vuetify (not sure if this should be considered their issue ore Vue's)

---
Passing slots through to child components is, according to what you usually find on the net, done with this syntax:

```
<slot v-for="(_, name) in $slots" :name="name" :slot="name" />
<template v-for="(_, name) in $scopedSlots" :slot="name" slot-scope="slotData"><slot :name="name" v-bind="slotData" /></template>
```
Unfortunately this uses the slot and slot-scope attributes which are marked as deprecated.
As a current replacement, the following syntax seems to be the correct one:
```
<template v-for="(_, name) in $scopedSlots" v-slot:[name]="slotData">
  <slot :name="name" v-bind="slotData"/>
</template>
<template v-for="(_, name) in $slots" v-slot:[name]>
  <slot :name="name"/>
</template>
```
Unfortunately this does not give the same result as the old syntax. Depending on the order in which scoped and non-scoped slots are passed, either scoped slots are not passed at all or non-scoped slots are only passed in $scopedSlots, which Vuetify (and maybe other libraries?) ignores for slots that are not supposed to be scoped.

<!-- generated by vue-issues. DO NOT REMOVE -->
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Passing slots through in wrapper component" (#11478)

Issues.Title: Navigation bug in vue-router >= 3.3.0
Issues.Body:
### Version
3.3.4 (but it exists since 3.3.0)

### Reproduction link
[https://github.com/sqal/vue-router-navigation-bug](https://github.com/sqal/vue-router-navigation-bug)

### Steps to reproduce
1. Clone my repository, run `npm i && npm run serve`
2. Click on the following links

- Go to /users
- Go to /users/1

3. Go back to the previous page. At this point, you can notice that navigation is broken, because instead of users page Vue still renders the user page and clicking back again doesn't work, it still renders the last visited route.

### What is expected?
vue-router should display correct route

### What is actually happening?
To understand why this bug occurs you need to look at [this line of code](https://github.com/sqal/vue-router-navigation-bug/blob/master/src/router/index.js#L16l).  Even though I've added some comments there I'll try and explain what this code does. I added noop beforeEach hook there because I want to prevent a resolution of the initial route meaning I don't want to show dashboard or login page before the authentication check is resolved. Only after the user is authenticated (or not) I am calling `resolveRoute` function and redirecting the user to the correct page. This worked great with vue-router <= 3.2.0, but something has changed in the newer version and I can't figure out how to fix it in my code or if it has to be fixed inside a vue-router. Anyway, I would appreciate any help you could provide. Thanks

<!-- generated by vue-issues. DO NOT REMOVE -->
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Navigation bug in vue-router >= 3.3.0" (#3245)

Issues.Title: vue-router duplicates router-view contents when using prerender-spa-plugin
Issues.Body:
### Version
3.2.0

### Reproduction link
[https://github.com/RudolfVonKrugstein/vue-prerender-test](https://github.com/RudolfVonKrugstein/vue-prerender-test)







### Steps to reproduce
I am reporting this for vue-router, but I am not sure if it is really a problem with the vue-router component or some other tool in the toolchain I am using.

1. Check out the provided git repository, which has been created the following way
  * A new project has been created with `vue create pre-render-test` and setup with typescript and vue-router
  * Vuetify has been added using `vue add vuetify`
  * [prerender-spa-plugin](https://github.com/chrisvfritz/prerender-spa-plugin) has been added and configured (see [vue.config.js](https://github.com/RudolfVonKrugstein/vue-prerender-test/blob/master/vue.config.js))
2. Build for production using `yarn build`
3. Run a simple http server, for example like this:
    cd dist
    python3 -m http.server
4. go to localhost:8000/about

### What is expected?
The about page, just showing

```
This is an about page
```

### What is actually happening?
The about page is duplicated:

```
This is an about page
This is an about page
```

---
Looking at the DOM I can see, that not the whole app is duplicated but only the contents of `router-view`.
It also seems that some unrelated changes to the project (like adding a toolbar) makes the problem disappear, or re-appear.
Maybe it is some sort of race condition?

<!-- generated by vue-issues. DO NOT REMOVE -->

Issues.Title: `onReady` triggers the onError callback with a redirection
Issues.Body:
<!--
IMPORTANT: Please use the following link to create a new issue:

  https://new-issue.vuejs.org/?repo=vuejs/vue-router

If your issue was not created using the app above, it will be closed immediately.
-->


This is a regression introduced in 3.3.0:


Given this code:

```js
router.beforeEach((to, from, next) => {
  if (to.path === '/') next('/foo')
  else next()
})

router.onReady(() => {
console.log('good')
}, err => {
  console.log(err)
})
```

The initial navigation would trigger the second callback passed to onReady instead of the first one. This is because the Redirection Error is now visible instead of `undefined`
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "`onReady` triggers the onError callback with a redirection" (#3225)

Issues.Title: Navigation guard redirect causes errors when navigating programmatically
Issues.Body:
### Version
3.3.2

### Reproduction link
[https://codesandbox.io/s/vue-router-zb7l4](https://codesandbox.io/s/vue-router-zb7l4)







### Steps to reproduce
Click on Navigate button. It will trigger navigation via `router.push` which will cause an error.

### What is expected?
User gets silently redirected to location that was passed to `next(...)` in navigation guard.

### What is actually happening?
Call to `router.push` throws an error, but the redirect still happens.

---
In my app, users that have not completed initial setup process after signup should be redirected to setup page. There is a navigation guard for this: if user has not completed setup, do a redirect. When user logs in, app redirects him to home page via `router.push()`. And when user has not finished setup process, this will cause an error.

This behavior seems to be introduced in 3.3.0 by this commit https://github.com/vuejs/vue-router/commit/4c727f9

I don't know whether this is a bug or intentional behavior. If it's intentional, why was it introduced? For me it seems counter-intuitive that a simple redirect causes an error.

<!-- generated by vue-issues. DO NOT REMOVE -->
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Navigation guard redirect causes errors when navigating programmatically" (#3224)

Issues.Title: Calls to mutations and  actions don't get cancelled when a module is unregistered using `unregisterModule`
Issues.Body:
### Version
3.4.0

### Reproduction link
[https://codesandbox.io/s/mutation-call-after-unregistermodule-v4n3z](https://codesandbox.io/s/mutation-call-after-unregistermodule-v4n3z)







### Steps to reproduce
1. Make sure the first page you see is the `Home` page.
2. Click on `Contact` button and immediately click on `Home`
3. Observe the Console.



### What is expected?
No errors. When the module is unregistered, any running action or mutation calls should also be cancelled.

### What is actually happening?
The action/mutation code keeps executing and user sees errors in the Console stating that the module does not exist.
`[vuex] unknown local mutation type: setContact, global type: contact/setContact`

---
There are 2 components: `Home.vue` and `Contact.vue`. `Contact.vue` calls an action in it's `mounted` callback. The action `changeContact` mimics the behaviour of an API call and commits a mutation after a delay of 1 second.

What I am trying to do is that when user navigates from one page to another, the modules of the first route should be unregistered. This can be done easily using the `unregisterModule` method. The problem is that any action or mutation calls executed before the unregistering are not removed and they throw errors in the browser Console.

In the above sandbox, when user switches from Contact to Home immediately, following things happen:
- `Contact.vue` loads and it's mounted callback is called.
- Inside the `mounted` callback, the `changeContact` action is called
- User goes back to Home. This calls `beforeDestroy` of `Contact.vue` that un-registers the `contact` module.
- The `changeContact` tries to call the `setContact` mutation, but, since the module does not exist, an error message is thrown in the Console `[vuex] unknown local mutation type: setContact, global type: contact/setContact`

<!-- generated by vue-issues. DO NOT REMOVE -->
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Calls to mutations and  actions don't get cancelled when a module is unregistered using `unregisterModule`" (#1767)

Issues.Title: Slow registerModule when the module has getters
Issues.Body:
### Version
3.5.1

### Reproduction link
[https://jsfiddle.net/qaL8f36y/](https://jsfiddle.net/qaL8f36y/)







### Steps to reproduce
0. Open the link
1. Specify any number > 0 for 'getters'
2. Click Generate Modules
3. Click Generate Modules

I was unable to generate more than about 3000 getters in total before the browser crashed.

Without the link, call Store.registerModule to register 1000s of modules with a single getter (or fewer modules with more getters) to see the browser run out of resources.

You can test out creating modules without getters and notice that the time taken is more-or-less constant (~45ms for me)

### What is expected?
Registering modules with getters should perform the same as modules without getters

### What is actually happening?
Performance of Store.registerModule when the module has getters is compounding, the more getters you have the slower it is to add more modules with getters.

---
I'm using dynamic modules as a pattern to handle 'collections of objects' in the store while avoiding needing to pass the index (or object key) around in getters, mutators, etc. Similar to https://stackoverflow.com/questions/44345704/separating-vuex-stores-for-dynamically-created-components - I have hundreds of objects in the store that are treated this way.

I noticed an issue when using the dev tools as the dev tools would frequently crash, and sometimes the page would too. There were repeated warning in the console `[Violation] 'setTimeout' handler took 1552ms` where the time was increasing each time, which I took to mean something wasn't linear/constant time. I finally took the time to create a minimal reproduction but found the issue was present without Vue/Vuex devtools open, though the numbers needed to crash the browser were larger without devtools.

<!-- generated by vue-issues. DO NOT REMOVE -->
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Slow registerModule when the module has getters" (#1792)

Issues.Title: Vuex hasModule
Issues.Body:
### Version
3.4.0

### Reproduction link
[https://codesandbox.io/s/hasmodule-inconsistent-with-string-x58fh?file=/src/App.vue](https://codesandbox.io/s/hasmodule-inconsistent-with-string-x58fh?file=/src/App.vue)







### Steps to reproduce
Check for the existence of a nested module with a string, vs an array path.

### What is expected?
I would expect checking with a string or an equivalent array to produce the same result.

### What is actually happening?
Checking `hasModule` with a string returns false, while checking it with an equivalent array returns true.

---
I suppose this could be intentional, but it seems like a bug.  If it's not intentional it seems like a simple fix:

Line 219 in `src/store.js ` currently is:

```if (typeof path === 'string') path = [path]```

It seems like simply changing that to the following will fix the problem:

```if (typeof path === 'string') path = path.split("/")```

Thoughts?

<!-- generated by vue-issues. DO NOT REMOVE -->
